descendants.content: Caveat: I’m referring, of course, to personal car ownership, to one person driving himself around in a 2000-pound vehicle instead of using public transit. In certain cases, such as people with different abilities, taxi or ride share options should be made available if there are no better choices.

account.note:

Retired NGO executive doing my best to stay informed and raise awareness about environmental crises, climate breakdown, and the rapacious, murderous impact of greedy capitalists and the politicians they own.

Why the name? Back in the day, empires placated their citizens with "bread and circuses." Now we get fast food and apps. But it's all basically the same — distraction from what's REALLY happening.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses

I've made similar suggestions, except EVs seem ok to ne cities.

Starting by making cities oil-car free seems like the right way to go because it can be done much faster.

Cities have only short distances so battery size is not an issue. And the density is high enough that supporting many chargers and easy access to rescue services is easier to achieve. Intercity that's harder. We need better bus networks between cities.

Side benefits: less noise, better air in cities.

descendants.content:
@hurt138
>I fully believe we need less of everything I just don't see how we can get there outside a system like Cuba?

----

That has been Jørgen Raders (limits to growth coauthors) point for decades, democracy is the problem. You just have to look to the US, how many will vote D or R and ensure "nothing" changes ? US under Biden extracts more oil and gas then it ever has.

We can post solutions all day but all they are is blah blah blah.as emisisna keep rising.

We have all the solutions we need eg bicycles. This is not a issue of a lack of science or engineering. This is human entitlement vs the laws of nature and while we can fool ourselves and each other for a time, the laws of nature will always prevail. You can't terraform the planet with Gt of GHGs and other pollutants and not expect it to change, Jørgen etal pointed out way back in the 1970s.

https://www.nationalobserver.com/2024/06/14/opinion/science-civilization-collapse-environment-limits

>Rees bluntly states, “the human enterprise is effectively subsuming the ecosphere” and “wide-spread societal collapse cannot be averted — collapse is not a problem to be solved, but rather the final stage of a cycle to be endured.”

----

https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/may/07/un-expert-human-rights-climate-crisis-economy

>Outgoing special rapporteur David Boyd says ‘there’s something wrong with our brains that we can’t understand how grave this is’

@RichardAshwell @breadandcircuses

card.title: The world is facing a 'semi-dystopian' future
card.description: If our present path doesn't change drastically, the science seems to suggest we are likely to experience a collapse of civilization — and we'll have nobody but ourselves to blame.

descendants.content:
@largess @hurt138 @RichardAshwell @breadandcircuses

Spot on ✊🏽 You might well enjoy the late David Fleming's exceptional perspective, for this was his starting point.

Where does it leave us if we accept that there is too much economic, cultural and political momentum behind growth for any great turning to ecological sanity..?

I can fairly say that it transformed my life — showing me a beautiful path of neither denial nor despair — and I am deeply grateful for it:
https://leanlogic.online/introduction-david-fleming/

#Methane (#CH₄) is a also a potent #GreenhouseGas which, in my view, makes so-called 'natural gas' dirtier than coal. The FF industry, and governments, deliberately ignore most of the leakage in production and transmission. Here are the latest observations: https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/trends_ch4/

card.title: Citizens' Assembly - Extinction Rebellion UK
card.description: We know the world is spinning towards catastrophe. We know it’s time to act. If we are going to avoid disaster, we will have to make difficult choices for the long term, collaboratively, in a fair way that isn’t biased towards a powerful or wealthy minority. We need to modernise the political system so that it can deal with the problems of today's world, and work better for everyday people. To do that it has to include everyday people.That’s why we need a Citizens’ Assembly on Climate and Ecological Justice to break the deadlock and to put fairness and justice at the centre of decision-making.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses Yes but,
a requirement for that is that public transport becomes way better.
Forbidding people from commuting into town by car, in a world where trains go every hour or less is not an option.
Regional train departures would have to be at 10min intervals.
And there would have to be a system that would allow people from the countryside to drive to the edge of that "no car zone", put their car into a multiple story tall parking garage and easily take a bus/tram downtown. Preferably with inner city public transportation departing every 5 minutes.
